verses.text: Then he said to Moses, 'Come up to Yahweh, you and Aaron, Nadab and Abihu, and seventy of the elders of Israel, and worship from a distance.'
verses.comment: Names are transliterated; Yahweh is used for faithfulness to the original Hebrew.

verses.text: Moses alone shall come near to Yahweh, but the others shall not come near, and the people shall not go up with him.
verses.comment: Repeated emphasis on separation between Moses and others matches Hebrew.

verses.text: Moses came and told the people all the words of Yahweh and all the ordinances, and all the people answered with one voice and said, 'All the words that Yahweh has spoken we will do.'
verses.comment: Ordinances rendered for 'judgments' (mishpatim); theological commitment clear.

verses.text: And Moses wrote down all the words of Yahweh. Early in the morning he built an altar at the foot of the mountain, and twelve pillars for the twelve tribes of Israel.
verses.comment: Twelve pillars symbolizes Israel’s tribes; matches original meaning.

verses.text: And he sent young men of the sons of Israel, who offered burnt offerings and sacrificed peace offerings of oxen to Yahweh.
verses.comment: ‘Peace offerings’ for 'shelemim;' sacrificial terms kept literal.

verses.text: And Moses took half of the blood and put it in basins, and half of the blood he threw against the altar.
verses.comment: ‘Threw’ matches Hebrew ‘zarak’, often ‘sprinkle’ or ‘dash’. Readability preserved.

verses.text: Then he took the book of the covenant and read it in the hearing of the people, and they said, 'All that Yahweh has spoken we will do, and we will be obedient.'
verses.comment: ‘Book of the covenant’ indicates written record; literal phrase kept.

verses.text: And Moses took the blood and threw it on the people and said, 'See, the blood of the covenant that Yahweh has made with you concerning all these words.'
verses.comment: ‘Threw’ used here as in v6, emphasizing ritual act.

verses.text: Then Moses and Aaron, Nadab and Abihu, and seventy of the elders of Israel went up.
verses.comment: Faithful to the original word order and structure.

verses.text: And they saw the God of Israel. Under his feet was something like a pavement of sapphire, clear as the sky itself.
verses.comment: Phrase ‘pavement of sapphire’ follows Hebrew closely; ‘clear as the sky’ literal.

verses.text: But he did not stretch out his hand against the nobles of the sons of Israel; they saw God, and they ate and drank.
verses.comment: ‘Stretch out his hand’—idiom for judgment—retained for faithfulness.

verses.text: Yahweh said to Moses, 'Come up to me on the mountain and stay there. I will give you the tablets of stone and the law and the commandments that I have written, so that you may teach them.'
verses.comment: ‘Law and commandments’ matches Hebrew; phrasing modernized for clarity.

verses.text: So Moses rose up with Joshua his assistant, and Moses went up into the mountain of God.
He said to the elders, 'Wait here for us until we return to you. Look, Aaron and Hur are with you. Whoever has a dispute, let him go to them.'
verses.comment: Phrase ‘let him go to them’ is faithful to Hebrew; Aaron and Hur identified as leaders.

verses.text: Then Moses went up into the mountain, and the cloud covered the mountain.
verses.comment: ‘Cloud covered’ follows Hebrew imagery without embellishment.

verses.text: The glory of Yahweh settled on Mount Sinai, and the cloud covered it for six days. On the seventh day he called to Moses out of the midst of the cloud.
verses.comment: ‘Settled’ for ‘dwelled’ (‘shakan’); ‘midst of the cloud’ matches original.

verses.text: Now the appearance of the glory of Yahweh was like a consuming fire on the top of the mountain in the eyes of the sons of Israel.
verses.comment: ‘Consuming fire’ kept literal, imagery emphasized as in Hebrew.

verses.text: And Moses entered the cloud and went up into the mountain. Moses was on the mountain forty days and forty nights.
verses.comment: ‘Entered the cloud’ literal; ‘forty days and forty nights’ phrase preserved per original.
